bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, October 21, 1922

div1.p: Hanson writes about resuming his yellow fever work in Mexico. He discusses the ramifications, both personal and financial, that such a decision would entail. He comments on the political situation in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, October 21, 1922
div1.opener:
File
I. H. B.
Hanson
Oct. 21, 1922 2300 Summit Ave
Sioux City, I a.
My dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I was and
still am very sorry that you
happened to be out of town at the
time I came to Washington last
week. However I had to good
fortune to meet Laura, and
had a very pleasant and profit-
able visit with her. I now
realize more fully how much
you think of her. She is truly
a wonderful girl.

I presume Laura has told you
what the object of my visist to
Washington was, and what my
action in the matter. I am
still a little unsettled in my
mind as to what might be the
proper course to pursue. I dont
quite see why they should still
arebe having difficulty in controlling
the fever in Mexico. There may
be some conditions which I do
not know or understand to explain
their trouble.

The plan proposed by White was
for me to go down and take charge
of the district of Yucatan about
Meredia, and sort of watch the
situation, with an eventual
possibility of taking a more gener-
al charge of the Mexican situation.

The suggestion was also made that
there might later be some work
in Brazil and Africa, this however
seems a little uncertain as far as
I am concerned. Seems like there
is too much uncertainty in the
policy, and I dont see much use
of my taking one of those minor
subordinate positions, as long
as they have a number of Physicians
there who have been in the work
for some time. They would no
doubt resent it if I should
come in a supervisory capacity.

It appears to me that I could take
a hold of the Mexican proposition,
with a few of my old staff and
assure the finish of it in a rela-
tively short time. However the
longer they draw that thing out the
more impatient the people are going
to be and the more difficult it will
be to finish the thing up as it
should be.

I told White that I could not
very well consider going to Mexico
for any less than I was getting while
in charge of the Y. F. work in Peru
which was $1000.00 per mo. One
has a great many unavoidable ex-
penses for the family when one
moves about unsettled on these
foreign details and it is a very
different proposition for married
men from that of the single man
or a married man without children.

There are several propositions in
this country, some pay in about
C1
B20
$6000.00 per year, and if a person
could get settled, it would pay better
to do so; - besides it would enable
me to do a fair amount of home
work, which I ought to be doing
right now in connection with
writing up several phases of the
work in Peru.

I am finding it rather difficult to read-
just my self to the conditions prevailing
and am at a loss to know what I should
decide to do and where. We used to
talk a great deal about Peruvian poli-
tics - but there are also some politics
right here in the U. S. A., and there
seem to be some in the Am. Pub. H. A.
I just attended the Cleveland meeting
but am not sure that it paid to do so.

What I would like most of all if it
were possible would be to have an
assignment to do antimalaria and
general field sanitary work but that
I presume is quite out of the question.

The climate up here does not seem
to agree with the children. Martha
has just had a pretty bad cold almost
like a flu, and Virgil is quite sick
better to day than yesterday, but shows some
ear trouble. Will have his ear looked at.
